profiles.name: PHIL - Level 6 Midterm Exams - Fall 2025 Bimestre 1
profiles.prompt:
Write a follow-up email.

You recently had a meeting with a potential client, ABC Tech Solutions, where you discussed a new software package your company offers. During the meeting, you addressed the client's concerns and provided them with a detailed proposal.

Now, a week has passed, and you have not received any feedback. Write a polite and professional follow-up email to the client, Ms. Claire Roberts, to:

Gently remind her about the proposal.
Offer to answer any questions she may have.
Express your willingness to move forward with next steps or set up another meeting.
Write your email in 250 – 270 words. Don’t forget to use linking words to make your text easier for the reader to understand. 

It is mandatory to use at least:

6 grammar structures (subjunctive sentences, etc.) seen in class. Write the grammar sentences between parentheses ().
4 linkers. Write the linkers between *asterisks*.
10 vocabulary items (expressions to discuss possibility, worplace dynamics vocabulary, phrases to talk about data, vocabulary to discuss insights and interpretations etc.) seen in class. Write the vocabulary items in CAPITAL LETTERS.

profiles.name: PHIL - Level 5 Midterm Exams - Fall 2025 Bimestre 1
vocabulary: Prefixes (any word using these counts as vocab used):
Suffixes (any word using these counts as vocab used):
grammar: Active vs. Passive verb forms (all tenses, modals)
Review reporting verbs with verb patterns:
Reporting verb + clause (agree, promise, suggest, complain, admit, explain, mention, claim)
Reporting verb + direct object + clause (advise, warn, tell, convince, assure, persuade, notify, inform, remind)
Reporting verb + infinitive (threaten, demand, offer, propose, refuse, ask, agree, claim, promise)
Reporting verb + direct object + infinitive (invite, tell, beg, forbid, order, remind, advise, ask, encourage, warn [not to])
Reporting verb + verb + ing (mention, deny, suggest, recommend, admit, propose)
Reporting verb + preposition + verb + ing (agree [to], apologize [for], insist [on], argue [about])
Reporting verb + direct object + preposition + verb + ing (blame [for], congratulate [on], discourage [from], criticize [for])
profiles.prompt:
Write a letter to a younger friend.

Write a letter to a younger friend who is interested in starting his/her own business. In this letter, share your insights on the importance of entrepreneurship and innovation. Highlight how innovative thinking can lead to successful ventures and provide practical advice on taking the first steps.

 

Follow the specific pattern:

Paragraph 1: Introduce the topic of entrepreneurship and express your excitement about your friend’s interest in starting a business.
Paragraph 2: Discuss the significance of innovation in entrepreneurship. Use reported speech to include a quote or advice from a successful entrepreneur you admire (e.g., Steve Jobs, Elon Musk, etc.)
Paragraph 3: Share practical steps your friend can take to start his/her entrepreneurial journey. Use conditional sentences to discuss potential scenarios
Paragraph 4: Summarize your main points and encourage your friend to embrace his/her entrepreneurial spirit.
Write your essay in 200 – 220 words. Don’t forget to use linking words to make your text easier for the reader to understand. You can include the following sentence to your text:

A mentor once advised me that taking calculated risks is essential for success because …

 

It is mandatory to use at least:

6 grammar structures seen in class. Write the it between parentheses ().
4 linkers. Write the linkers between *asterisks*.
10 vocabulary items seen in class. Write the vocabulary items in CAPITAL LETTERS.

profiles.prompt:
The students are instructed to write about the following:
Write a narrative text about what happened last time you went to the doctor, incorporating reported speech, indirect questions, narrative tenses, and vocabulary related to health and medicine (going to the doctor).

Follow the specific pattern:

Paragraph 1: How you got to the doctor’s office. Use narrative tenses to set the scene.
Paragraph 2: How you got the appointment. Include indirect questions to reflect on your thoughts or what you wanted to ask. 
Paragraph 3: What the doctor told you. Incorporate reported speech to convey what the doctor said and how you responded.
Paragraph 4: How the story ended. Use vocabulary related to health and medicine (going to the doctor).
Write your essay in 150 – 170 words. Don’t forget to use storytelling elements to engage the reader. You can add the following sentence to your story:

As I settled into the waiting room, I noticed … 

It is mandatory to use at least:
4 linkers. Write the linkers between *asterisks*.
10 vocabulary items (adverbs of time, going to the doctor, media, high-frequency verb collocations, etc.) seen in class. Write the vocabulary items in CAPITAL LETTERS.
